Subject: Competitive coevolution, multiple fitness scores per genome question
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=190115458; y=stfU9ISL6_5BNXJlAgboudG1U5V4pdfTBCcxN_5xWuoV1-g30bRxmJwu1j9stX_kvliahQr0ut5MGo8
X-Yahoo-Profile: ze_dakster

Ken,

I'm in the process of coding up a "remake" of the robot duel experime=
nt from your paper on evolutionary complexification, and I had a question r=
egarding having multiple fitness scores per host. 

So you have 12 opponent=
s per host genome, played twice (east/west start). I see you're combining t=
he east/west scores into a single fitness score per opponent, but it sounds=
 like from the paper you're ending up with 12 fitness scores per host genom=
e per generation (or more likely I'm too tired to interpret the paper corre=
ctly). 

I'm my current robot duel implementation I'm simply combining all =
24 of these evaluations into a single fitness score passed into the end-of-=
generation "epoch" method in my NEAT implementation (basically a Linux port=
 of Mat Buckland's windows implementation setup as C++ classes). 

At least=
 in the implementation I currently have, you can only have one fitness scor=
e per genome in the population.

Am I correct in combining them, or did you=
 do something else under the hood there with multiple fitness scores per ge=
nome?
